speak;Ross;You must think I'm pretty gullible!|You can't trick me like that!
speak;Amelia;But I'm telling the truth!|I am on your side!|I didn't attack you.|I tripped and fell into you, but it was an accident!
speak;Ross;Right...|Let's say for a second I buy this story.|But how can you explain tripping when there's nothing around to trip on?
speak;Amelia;There was a dent over there, and-
speak;Ross;Huh?|Oh, you mean that.|I see.|You tripped on that thing, huh?
speak;Ross;How could you have tripped on that?|I can barely even see it!|Hey, isn't that spear a little heavy for you?|You're so small.|Need a little help?
speak;Amelia;Not really.|It's much lighter than other knights'.|I'm working on building up more power, but I'm getting the hang of it.
speak;Ross;Hmmm...|I noticed that your armor is very shiny.
speak;Amelia;Um, yes.|Thanks, I guess.|I'm always polishing it.
speak;Ross;That's a sure sign of a new recruit!|Watch out for hazing.|You might as well be wearing a sign taped to your forehead that says “I'm a rookie!”
speak;Ross;But in exchange, you must cover ME when someone attacks me with a sword!
speak;Amelia;Thank you...|for believing me that I'm not your enemy.
speak;Ross;There's no point in fighting with someone on your own side.|OK, let's go!
speak;Ross;I guess I haven't told you my name, huh.|I'm Ross, the son of the warrior Garcia.
speak;Amelia;I'm Amelia.|Nice to meet you, Ross.
speak;Ross;Likewise.|By the way, it looks like you're getting better at battle.
speak;Amelia;Yes.|It's mostly because you and others are helping me out.|I'm also getting the hang of my spear.

speak;Ross;I see.|I was once a rookie too.|Everyone has to start somewhere.|We're young, and we start at the bottom of the chain, you know?|But we'll get stronger, both of us.|So let's work hard, all right?
speak;Ross;I have something for you.|Now, where did I put it?|Hmm...|Ah, here it is.
speak;Ross;I bought it.|I mean, I bought it a long time go.|There was a kid selling this on the street, and he just wouldn't leave me alone.|I didn't need it, but he seemed really hungry, so...
speak;Amelia;That's very kind of you, Ross.
speak;Ross;Oh, it's not a big deal.|A-anyway, it's yours now.
speak;Amelia;It's not that.|It's very pretty!|It's just...
speak;Ross;You should have just accepted in the first place.|Why are you acting so reluctant?
speak;Ross;Huh?|What's that got to do with it?
speak;Amelia;I could never afford something like this...|So to me, everything is so very precious...|And I couldn't take something that was precious to you...
speak;Ross;I see.|Please just take it and enjoy it.
speak;Ross;Of course!|Besides, I've always looked better in earrings than necklaces.|Just kidding!|OK, let's go, Amelia.
speak;Ross;Hey, Amelia.|I heard you're getting better.
speak;Ross;Well, it's a hard road to get to where we think we should be.

speak;Ross;As for me, my father was always the warrior in the family.|I've always wanted to be just like him.|I think I'm just finally starting to get close to that goal.|But anyways, how are your parents?
speak;Amelia;I don't talk about them much...
speak;Ross;Oh! Um...|I'm sorry.|I didn't mean to...
speak;Amelia;No, no.|It's fine.|My father has been gone for as long as I can remember...|I was living with my mother, but...
speak;Amelia;But she is...no longer with me.
speak;Ross;I see...|Sounds like you've had a rough life...
speak;Ross;I'm sorry I brought up something painful.
speak;Ross;Um...|I've got it!|I'll be your big brother!
speak;Amelia;What in the world are you talking about?

speak;Ross;Your brother!|And you'll be my sister!|Yeah!|This is the best idea I've had in a while!|It doesn't matter that we're not blood relatives.|The army is like a family, so we are like siblings!|So it's decided, then.|You're my little sister from now on.|So you're not alone anymore.|You can call me big brother, OK?
speak;Amelia;Um...|This is all kind of...sudden.|I don't know if I'm ready to-
speak;Ross;Never mind all that!|We're brother and sister from now on.|All right, Sis?
speak;Ross;Huh?|What's that got to do with it?
speak;Ross;You know...|Old enough to show you the ropes.
speak;Amelia;Wait a minute...|You're probably the same age as me!
speak;Amelia;In fact, I'll bet I'm a little older...
speak;Ross;Grrrrrr!|Be quiet!|I said I'm the big brother.|It doesn't matter the exact date we're born.|I'm the big brother.|Any way you look at it, I'm the older one!
speak;Amelia;Ha ha!|You're too funny!|It's so cute when you get mad!|Hee hee hee!
speak;Ross;Hmph!|When this war is over, I'll take you to my village.
speak;Ross;Haven't you been listening to anything?|We're brother and sister now, remember?
speak;Ross;From now on, you and I are going to share both joy and sorrow as a family.|OK?
speak;Amelia;If I didn't know better, I would think that you were proposing to me.|Ha ha ha!
speak;Ross;What!|That's not what I'm talking about at all!|You twisted my words up!|Just forget it!|Anyways, let's go!

name: SupportRossAndEwan
_source: speak;Ross;Here you are.|I finally tracked you down.
speak;Ross;Hey, Ewan.|Nice to meet you.|I've been looking for someone around my age.|Let's hang out sometime, OK?
speak;Ewan;Sure, but do we have to wait until “sometime”?|How about now?
speak;Ross;What are you saying?|We're in the middle of a battle!

speak;Ewan;The others are fighting well, so the two of us won't make much difference.|Besides, even though I just started using magic the other day, I'm pretty good.|If something does happen, we'll be OK.
speak;Ross;Well, I'm pretty confident in my skills, too.|But, you know-how to put this delicately- it's the matter of morale.
speak;Ewan;You certainly are dedicated.|That's a surprise.
speak;Ewan;Why don't you prove your dedication by answering this brainteaser?
speak;Ewan;Yes.|It'll be really fun to watch you struggling to come up with an answer.|Ha!
speak;Ross;Hey!|What's that supposed to mean?|Well, whatever.|Let's do it.
speak;Ewan;OK, here it is.|Ross, do you know what a balance is?
speak;Ross;Of course I do!|Who doesn't?|It's a type of scale with small plates on both sides to put weights.|When both sides are the same weight, it balances.|So that was the riddle?|Easy!
speak;Ewan;Ha ha ha!|You're too funny!|No, that was just the setup for the brainteaser.|Here's the real question.|Assume there are 25 pebbles.
speak;Ewan;Yes, they're really small.|As small as peas.|They are all the same color and shape.|In this group, there's one pebble that's lighter than all the other pebbles.
speak;Ross;And I must tell you the way to find that pebble?
speak;Ewan;Of course not.|What kind of challenge is that?|The question is, how many times do you need to use the balance to find that one rock?
speak;Ross;How many times?|Uh...|It's not...24, is it?
speak;Ewan;What?!|Oh! Ha ha ha ha ha!|That's the first time I've heard that one!|I see.|So you were thinking that you'd measure the pebbles one by one!|That's great, Ross!|You're too funny!
speak;Ross;That's not a compliment, is it.|You think I'm an idiot!
speak;Ewan;That's not true.|Actually, it is.|Ha ha ha!|And did I mention how perceptive you are, too?
speak;Ross;Oh, you!|Just you wait!|I'll figure it out!|I just need some time to think about it.
speak;Ross;I have an answer for your brainteaser!
speak;Ewan;You must have worked really hard to figure that out!
speak;Ross;See!|See!|I told you I'd get it!|Fighting's not the only thing I'm good at.
speak;Ewan;However, that's not the correct answer.
speak;Ross;What do you mean?|I can't believe it!|Ugh!|If that's not the right answer, then what is?
speak;Ewan;You were close.|The right answer is three times.

speak;Ewan;The key is how many pebbles you put on the scales at first.|First, put eight rocks each on either side of the scale.|The side with the lighter rock will be higher than the other, right?|Or, if the sides are balanced, it means that the lighter rock is in the rest of the pile.|So that was one turn on the balance.|The rest is pretty easy to figure out.|Let's assume that the lighter rock was in the remaining pile of nine rocks...|Then you'd put three rocks on each side of the scale.|So that's the second turn.|If either side of the scale tips, then the rock is in one of those two piles.|If the scale is balanced, then the rock is one of the remaining three rocks.|So, now you've figured out which group of three pebbles has the lighter one.|What you do now is put one rock from this pile on each side of the scale.|Like before, if the scale tips to one side, the lighter pebble is on the scale.|If the scale is balanced, then the remaining pebble is the lighter one.|And that was the last turn on the scale.|Did you get all that?
speak;Ross;Huh?|Well, I think I got it...
speak;Ewan;What?!|I just explained it all very clearly.|You still don't get it?|That's really...
speak;Ewan;Um, nothing.|Forget it.|A ha ha ha ha!
speak;Ross;“A ha ha ha” what?|What do you mean “forget it”?
speak;Ewan;Anyway, it's been fun hanging out.|Let's get together again sometime, OK?
speak;Ross;It wasn't fun for me at all!|Hey!
speak;Ewan;That brainteaser was fun, huh?|Did you get it yet?
speak;Ross;I already told you I didn't have any fun!|If that's what you consider fun, you must have had a pretty bad childhood!
speak;Ewan;My sister and I were abandoned when I was really young, before I could even talk.|She became a dancer and raised me all on her own.|I'm really grateful for her.
speak;Ross;You were an orphan?|I-I'm sorry.|I had no idea.

speak;Ewan;How could you know?|Don't worry about it.|I don't even remember being abandoned.|And because of that, I got a chance to travel around, and meet lots of people.|Like you.|So, I'm not sad at all.
speak;Ross;I see...|Hey, I just had a great idea.|Let's be brothers?
speak;Ewan;Huh?!|Like blood brothers?|I'm really not into slicing myself up for people I just met.
speak;Ross;No, no, no.|Just, you know, brothers!|Now call me “Bro,” Bro!
speak;Ross;Say it like you mean it!|Oh, never mind.|It'll just sound forced.
speak;Ross;Well, just call me Ross for now.|But, you can consider me a brother from now on.
speak;Ewan;What do you mean by that?
speak;Ross;I mean that I will be a friend who you can rely on and trust completely.
speak;Ewan;That's very kind, considering I really haven't known you for very long.|But thank you. You're a nice guy, even if you're not very sharp.
speak;Ross;Hey!|No need to insult me!|A simple “Thanks, Bro” will be enough!
speak;Ewan;Ha ha ha ha ha.|You're so funny!|By the way, do you have a girlfriend?
speak;Ross;W-what!|Of course not!|Did you forget?|We're in the middle of a war right now!|I have to focus on that!
speak;Ross;What's that for?|How about you?|Do you have one?
speak;Ewan;I have a lot of them!
speak;Ross;What?!|A lot of them!|Oh well.|We're still pretty young.|Better to not get tied down.
speak;Ross;Don't talk like it's not your problem, too!
speak;Ewan;Hey, Ross. I think we're going to be friends for a long time.|In fact, I know it.
speak;Ross;OK.|Boy, you're such a laid-back guy...

name: SupportRossAndGerik
_source: speak;Ross;Um...|Ahem.|Are you Sir Gerik by any chance?
speak;Ross;Oh, my name is Ross.|I'm the son of warrior Garcia.
speak;Gerik;I see......|So, Ross, are you an axeman?
speak;Ross;Yeah!|Don't be fooled by my appearance.|I'm actually pretty good.
speak;Gerik;Ha ha ha!|If you say so.
speak;Ross;Well, I think so.|But it's important to keep improving.
speak;Gerik;Why is that so important to you?

speak;Ross;My father is such an amazing warrior.|I've always wanted to be worthy of the title "son of Garcia."|And I want to be able to go home and rebuild my village.|After that, I want to go on a voyage and train in the open ocean.|And after that, I'd like to go back home.|To do all this, I need to be the best warrior I can be.
speak;Gerik;Those are admirable goals.|I'll help you out sometime.
speak;Ross;How?|You'll give me a lesson?|Are you serious?|That's great!
speak;Gerik;I might not be able to beat your father, but I could teach you a thing or two.|Why don't you try landing a hit on me?
speak;Ross;That'd be great!|But before we start, let me go practice on those guys first!
speak;Gerik;It's great that he's so eager to learn, but he's really not ready to go solo yet!
speak;Gerik;Ross, didn't you say that you wanted to go on an ocean voyage to train yourself?|The sea is a great place to train because it strengthens both the mind and body.
speak;Ross;Have you ever been on a voyage?

speak;Gerik;Of course.|I've escorted many commercial ships before.|It's embarrassing, but I got seasick for the first few days.|That was very painful.|But I got used to it in a few days.|It was a long trip.|Nature was more brutal than the enemies who pursued us.|But after the voyage ended, I realized that I grew up a lot.|The sea is an amazing combination of brutality and expansiveness.
speak;Ross;Now I definitely want to go on a sea voyage.
speak;Gerik;By the way, Ross, how's your injury from our last session?
speak;Ross;Oh, that little thing?|It healed right up!
speak;Gerik;Ha ha ha...|You sure are tough, boy!
speak;Ross;What should I do to be strong like you?
speak;Gerik;That's a tough question...|I would have to say that it's all in the mind.
speak;Gerik;If your desire to win is stronger than your opponent's, you've already won.|Your mind is your most important weapon.

speak;Ross;Come to think of it, I have noticed that.|At our last lesson, before we even started, I was thinking that I could never win.|I guess it was like admitting defeat before even trying.|All right! You've convinced me!|I'll start strengthening my mind as well as my axe skills.|Thank you, Sir Gerik.|I can't wait until our next lesson!
speak;Gerik;His energy is refreshing, but I must teach him patience next time.
speak;Gerik;What is it, Ross?|You seem down today.
speak;Ross;Why is the sword stronger than the axe?
speak;Gerik;What are you talking about?|Just use a stronger axe to beat a sword.
speak;Ross;That's not what I mean!|I want to be strong enough to split a silver sword with an iron axe.
speak;Gerik;He could defeat many swordsmen with just one axe.
speak;Ross;So you've seen him in battle?
speak;Gerik;Just once.|He was leading a unit of the Renais army.|He was swinging his axe at the front line.
speak;Ross;Wow, my dad was really strong, wasn't he!
speak;Gerik;He was more than just strong.|He was like a war god.|I have to be honest with you, Ross.|I was on his enemy side at the time.

speak;Gerik;I was a mercenary hired by the other side.|It was a fierce battle against Garcia's unit, and we ultimately had to retreat.|Come to think of it, this is a perfect example of the power of the mind.|You see, I was so intimidated by Garcia that I had lost even before I started.|That was an unforgettable failure for me.|After that, I swore to myself that I would be as strong as him with a sword.
speak;Ross;Wow, I can't believe Dad beat you down like that!|He's the greatest.|But you're pretty great, too.
speak;Gerik;Someone who lost to your father?

speak;Ross;Yeah!|You might have lost that time, but you became a great swordsman because of it!|OK.|I'm going to stop moping around.|From this moment on, I swear that someday I will destroy swords with my axe.|You are my witness, Sir Gerik!
speak;Gerik;Truly, you are the son of the warrior Garcia.
speak;Ross;That's not all!|I'm also the best student of the master swordsman Gerik!
speak;Gerik;When did you become my student?
speak;Ross;When I met you!|Oh!|Enemy detected!|I'll catch you later!|Give me another lesson someday, Sir Gerik.|I'll be much stronger by then, and maybe I'll win a match with you!
speak;Gerik;I believe he will surpass Garcia someday.

name: SupportNeimiAndAmelia
_source: speak;Neimi;Whoa...|That's beautiful!|Your armor, I mean.|It's so shiny.
speak;Amelia;Oh, my name is Amelia.|Nice to meet you, miss.
speak;Neimi;Miss?|Oh, no.|I'm just Neimi.|It's nice to meet you, too.
speak;Neimi;Anyway, your armor really is lovely.|That color reminds me of the michew berries that grow in my hometown.
speak;Amelia;Oh, I've had michew berries before!|They're really shiny, and they're sweet and a little tart when you eat them.|I just love them in pies...
speak;Neimi;Oh, I know!|I didn't think they grew anywhere else.|They're so yummy!
speak;Amelia;Tell you what.|If we come across any in the field, let's stop and pick them.
speak;Neimi;That sounds like a good idea.
speak;Amelia;Maybe we can use some of the supplies to bake some michew pies for everyone.|One bite, and they'll forget all about their exhaustion.
speak;Neimi;I agree.|I'll keep my eyes peeled, and if I see any, I'll pick some for you.
speak;Amelia;Ha ha!|That's great!|Now we've got something to look forward to, hm?|Oh, we'd better get back to the battle.
speak;Neimi;Aw...|All right, Amelia.|But let's talk some more again.
speak;Amelia;Oh, you bet!|I'm really glad I met you, Neimi.
speak;Neimi;Amelia, can I ask you a question?|Why did you become a soldier?
speak;Amelia;All my life, I've felt helpless, like I needed someone to defend me.|I didn't want to feel like that anymore.|But what about you, Neimi?|What are you fighting for?
speak;Neimi;I'm not really sure how I wound up getting involved in this whole war.|It just...sorta turned out that way, you know?

speak;Amelia;It doesn't matter how you wound up here.|Your skill with the bow is amazing, Neimi.|I'm not sure how to put this, but...|You seem more battle ready than most of the trained soldiers I've met.
speak;Neimi;Hmm mm mm...|Thanks.|My grandpa taught me everything I know.
speak;Neimi;We used to go hunting together when I was little...|Oh!|That reminds me!|I used to have a pet fox, a little kit I found out hunting one day.
speak;Amelia;Wow!|A fox kit?|I've never seen one before.|Was it cute?
speak;Neimi;He was adorable!|So small, and he had such soft and fluffy fur.|It was so cute watching him try to run his fastest on those short little legs.
speak;Neimi;What about you?|Did you ever have any pets?
speak;Amelia;Me?|Well, I don't-|Oh!|I did!|I used to have a little pet bird.
speak;Amelia;Hm.|Well, she had beautiful feathers, I remember that.|They were all blue and yellow and orange.|She used to sing to me.
speak;Neimi;She was a songbird?|That sounds nice.
speak;Amelia;It was.|Whenever I felt lonely, she would sing her song to cheer me up.|I let her go when I left my village and joined Grado's army.
speak;Neimi;That's so sad...|I think I'd like to get another pet when this war is all over.
speak;Neimi;Definitely.|You should get one, too.|Once this war is over, I mean.|When everything is at peace again, we should each get a pet.
speak;Amelia;That sounds great!|And then we can have our pets visit one another.
speak;Amelia;I just noticed something, Neimi.|There are a lot of female soldiers traveling with us, aren't there?
speak;Amelia;It's nice to see.|It wasn't like that in Grado's army.|It makes me feel much more at ease.
speak;Neimi;I was really nervous when I started up, but then I spoke more with the princess...

speak;Amelia;I've started noticing that some of the women are getting...friendly with the men.|I thought it was, you know, just the camaraderie of the field or whatever.|But I'm starting to think that's not the case, if you know what I mean.|I'm starting to think maybe it's something else entirely.
speak;Neimi;Hee hee hee...|So, um... Is there any boy you like?
speak;Amelia;Hm?|Why do you ask?|Or...is it that you have someone YOU like?
speak;Neimi;I do.|He's someone who's always watched over me, stood by my side.|He used to make me cry, but I...I love him.
speak;Amelia;That's amazing!|You know, I'm a little jealous of you...|Have you told him how you feel?
speak;Amelia;Well, you have to tell him!|I'm sure he likes you, too, Neimi.
speak;Neimi;I will.|Someday.|Not today.|But someday, I will.
speak;Neimi;But you never answered my question!
speak;Amelia;What, me?|I...er...|I honestly never really spoke to any of the men in Grado's army.
speak;Neimi;But you're not in Grado's army anymore!|What about now?
speak;Neimi;Don't worry.|I'm sure he likes you, Amelia.
speak;Neimi;Well, you're so...|You're so cute, and you're so nice.|How could anyone NOT like you?
speak;Amelia;Neimi...|Thanks.|That's really sweet of you.|I'm happy to hear you say that!
speak;Neimi;Be sure you tell him how you feel!
speak;Amelia;You, too!|I'm not the only one suffering here!
speak;Neimi;Hee hee hee.|All right.|We're in this together!

name: SupportNeimiAndArtur
_source: speak;Artur;Ah, Neimi.|I'm sorry that our introduction has been so delayed.|And please, just call me Artur.|"Brother" is too formal.
speak;Artur;Oh, nothing.|Sorry.|But...that hand mirror hanging from your waist...
speak;Neimi;Oh, this?|It's a keepsake from my mother.|I had it stolen from me once, so I've made this leather strap for it.|I can tie it to my belt and take it with me everywhere now.
speak;Artur;It's...|Excuse me, but may I look at it for a moment?

speak;Artur;Hm...|Yes, well, that is interesting.|If my memory serves, this is quite a valuable mirror.|It is a gift given only to clerics of the highest order.|Few of these mirrors exist, and for you to have one means your mother...
speak;Neimi;Yes, she was a cleric...|When I was young, an illness...

speak;Artur;Say no more.|I understand.|But seeing you and the mirror she left you tells me something.|Your mother was a good person, benevolent, faithful, and caring.|And you are the product of her care, filled with the same light.
speak;Neimi;Thank you...|It makes me happy to hear that.
speak;Artur;I'm delighted to have met you.|We shall have to speak again.
speak;Neimi;I hope so, Artur!|See you soon.
speak;Artur;Neimi, it's an honor to speak with you again so soon!
speak;Neimi;Oh!|Artur!|Yes, I'm happy to see you.
speak;Artur;That's an impressive bow.|Am I to understand that you're an archer?|I've heard the others speak highly of your skills.
speak;Neimi;Thank you.|And I was watching you use your magic.|It was pretty incredible!
speak;Artur;Oh, it was nothing.|I'm just a novice.|Oh!|Neimi, I see you've put your mirror away, have you?
speak;Neimi;Oh, no!|I've lost it!|What am I going to do?
speak;Artur;Lost!?|How could that happen!?|That mirror is a precious artifact, not to mention an important keepsake!
speak;Artur;Please don't cry.|Don't worry.|We'll look for it together.
speak;Artur;Any idea when you lost it?
speak;Neimi;I think I...sniff...had it with me when the battle started.|It was...right there on my belt...|Sniff...
speak;Artur;Then it must be around here somewhere, right?|I'll go look over here.|You check the ground back there.
speak;Artur;I couldn't find it here...|Any luck there?
speak;Artur;Don't worry.|It has to be around somewhere.|Just keep looking.|I'll ask the others, too.
speak;Neimi;All right...|I'll just go look over here...
speak;Artur;Oh, Neimi...|Sigh...|How am I ever going to find it in the middle of a battlefield?|I suppose I simply must have faith.|Yes, that's it.|Faith will guide me to her mother's mirror.

speak;Artur;I've been asking around since the last time we spoke.|I found out that our convoy master had found a mirror lying on the ground.|When I asked to see it, imagine my delight when I saw it was your mirror!
speak;Artur;You know, when I was looking for your mirror, I was reminded...|I had a similar experience when I was young.|It's why I chose to be a monk.

speak;Artur;One day, when I was just a little boy, I had lost a toy, and I was crying.|I lived near a monastery, and one of the monks saw me sitting there weeping.|He spent his day trying to find out why I was so sad and to cheer me up.|It was so trivial-that toy was nothing but a trinket, but to me, it had value.|I later found out a friend of mine had taken it without asking, but...|Anyway, I was very happy that someone had stopped to show so much concern.|To everyone else, I was just a petty child weeping over a toy.|To this monk, however, I was a sad and lost soul, crying out in need.|He was so kind, and he spent so much of his day on a child's tears.|I admired his attitude, even then.|It was then that I realized that I could honor his deed by becoming a monk.
speak;Artur;Your smile is delightful.|It's a vast improvement on those tears.|The heavens themselves must have wanted to see that smile and conspired to help me find your mirror.
speak;Artur;No, Neimi.|I'm grateful to you.|Talking to you makes me feel at peace.|I feel like...some of the others make light of me from time to time.
speak;Neimi;Oh, that's only...|It's just because you're so honest and pure of heart.|Someone I know...teases me a lot, too.|All the time, he teases me.
speak;Artur;I see...|I'm sorry to hear that.
speak;Neimi;Well, it's not that he's all bad.|He can be very kind, but...|But you're kind, too, Artur.

speak;Artur;Thank you.|You know, when you meet someone, that person reflects back at you like a mirror, revealing within them the emotions that you project.|Angry people bring out the anger within others, just as sullen, hopeless people bring out nothing but the sorrow within all those to whom they speak.|Do you know why so many people seem kind to you, Neimi?|It is because you yourself are a kind person.|You bring that out in others.
speak;Neimi;Oh, Artur...|That's so kind-|I mean... Er...|Thank you.
speak;Artur;Please, Neimi, always hold that kindness close to your heart.

name: SupportColmAndMarisa
_source: speak;Colm;Hey, you!|Have you seen a scary-looking woman?
speak;Colm;NO.|I don't have any sisters.|The woman I'm talking about was beautiful, but also very scary.|Have you seen someone who fits that description?
speak;Marisa;I don't think so.|Beautiful but very scary...|What do you mean by that?

speak;Colm;Well, I'm not exactly sure, either.|I just heard from one of Gerik's mercenaries that there is a woman sword fighter here.|Apparently, she's very talented and was hired for an unbelievable sum.
speak;Colm;Rumor is that if you speak to her without thinking, she's likely to attack you out of nowhere!
speak;Colm;Maybe her face is scarred from fighting.|Yeah, that's probably it!|She's beautiful, but has a very sad past behind that scar.|And that's why she's so scary!

speak;Colm;Or maybe it's because her lover was killed, and she's trying to avenge him.|That seems equally plausible, doesn't it?|Anyway, if you see her around, would you tell her that I was looking for her?|See ya.
speak;Marisa;Well, I'm the only female sword fighter here.|I guess he was looking for me.|He is so clueless...
speak;Colm;Oh, hi, Marisa!|I'm sorry for what I said the other day.|I figured out that you were the scary woman I was talking about.|I'm Colm. Nice to meet you.
speak;Marisa;OK.|So, what did you want from me?
speak;Colm;Oh, nothing special.|I just wanted to meet the famous swordswoman.|I was going to challenge you to a match, but I've seen you fight and know how good you are.|You'd beat me senseless.
speak;Marisa;I'll accept a match with you anytime.
speak;Colm;Well, I don't know how else to say this.|You're scaring me.
speak;Colm;Yeah.|It sounds funny, but you never look at the enemy...|I mean...you don't care about the enemy at all.
speak;Marisa;I have no idea what you're talking about.|Speak English.
speak;Colm;I mean...|Even when the enemy is right in front of you, you aren't even looking at him.|You're fighting something else.
speak;Colm;I'm not that smart, and I don't know much about swords.|So I can't say exactly who or what it is you are really fighting.
speak;Colm;Um...|What I mean to say is good luck in all your battles.|Um...|That's it.|See you later!
speak;Marisa;I was thinking about what you were saying the other day.
speak;Colm;You mean about you not fighting the enemy in front of you, but something else?|Is that what you're talking about?
speak;Marisa;Do you want to know?|What I'm really fighting with?
speak;Colm;Huh?|Y-yeah......|If you want to tell me, sure.
speak;Marisa;What I'm really fighting with is...
speak;Marisa;Well, to be more precise, his shadow.
speak;Marisa;He was one of the most famous swordsmen in Jehanna.|He was also a mercenary.
speak;Colm;I see why you're so good.
speak;Marisa;Ever since I was a child, my father taught me how to live as a mercenary.
speak;Marisa;The harsh conditions of Jehanna breed strength and ruthlessness.|The only way to survive is by being a mercenary.
speak;Marisa;My father is my parent, my teacher, and above all, a mountain I must conquer.
speak;Marisa;Once I conquer the mountain, I can accomplish anything I want.
speak;Colm;That must be a...big mountain.|So, where are you on the mountain?|A third of the way up?|Halfway up?|Or can you already see the summit?
speak;Colm;You still have a long way to go, huh?
speak;Marisa;...Yes.|I don't even know where the summit is yet.
speak;Colm;Well, then, you don't know how long it will take, do you?
speak;Marisa;I'll just keep climbing.|Even if it takes me forever...
speak;Colm;Oh.|I see.|Well, good luck.|I'm sure you'll make it to the top.
speak;Colm;Ha ha ha!|Oh, please.|You're embarrassing me.

name: SupportJoshuaAndMarisa
_source: speak;Joshua;Hey, I hear you're good with a sword...
speak;Joshua;It's a pleasure.|By the way, you ever hear this?

speak;Joshua;Well, I guess it was popular for a while, way back when.|But when two swordsmen met on the battlefield-even allied swordsmen-|they would duel it out to test one another's worth with the blade.|So what do you say?|Don't you think it's time to revive this tradition?
speak;Marisa;You want me to kill you?
speak;Joshua;No, no, no.|I'm not saying we have to fight to the death!|It's just a simple test of skill.
speak;Marisa;...Fine.|As long as I get a chance to whet my blade's appetite.
speak;Joshua;Er...|Great!|Now, what say we make this more interesting?|If I win, you owe me, and if you win, then I owe you.
speak;Joshua;...I'm not quite sure yet.|How about...|Ah, yes.|How about you owe me a favor.
speak;Marisa;But it doesn't matter.|I'm not going to lose to you.
speak;Joshua;Whoa!|Hold your horses!|Where's the hurry?|Let's do this another day.|After all, I like to savor the anticipation a little bit.
speak;Marisa;I don't get it, but fine.
speak;Joshua;Great!|We're all set then.|Next time we meet, we cross swords.|Deal?
speak;Marisa;There's nothing to anticipate.|You're simply going to lose.
speak;Joshua;Well, I don't know about that.|See you later.|I'm looking forward to it.
speak;Joshua;Whew...|After a match like that, I can be happy with a tie!
speak;Joshua;Heh...|Thanks.|But remember, I was at a slight disadvantage, so...

speak;Marisa;I must admit, I did hold you at a slight disadvantage.|However, we are closely matched, despite our incompatible styles.|I simply couldn't land a decisive blow.|But it was all worthwhile.|After all, I've learned, and that is worth far more than any wager.
speak;Joshua;I see.|You're a quick one, aren't you?|How did you get that good?
speak;Joshua;You live for the sword, eh?|I prefer rolling the dice to swinging the sword, you know?

speak;Joshua;Whew...|I thought you'd never ask.|You're asking how I got hooked on gambling, right?|Let me see...|There's not much to tell.|I guess by the time I realized it, it was already too late.|I'd grown bored of everything before I discovered gambling.|But then I saw it-gambling was like life, in short little bursts.|Life itself is just one big gamble!|That's how I see things.
speak;Marisa;I don't know anything about gambling, but it was a good duel.|We must try this again soon.
speak;Joshua;What, with no wager?|That doesn't sound very fun.
speak;Joshua;You mean that?|Then we'll have another bet.|I'll win next time.|See you later.
speak;Joshua;Whew...|Looks like I won this time.
speak;Joshua;No, you're just having a bad day.|And it's not like I had a decisive victory this time.|I'd say we're still just about even.
speak;Marisa;All that matters is that I didn't win.|You won the bet.|What do you want me to do?
speak;Joshua;Oh, you remembered our last bet!|That makes me happy.|All right, here goes...
speak;Joshua;I want you to be my partner for a while...|How's that sound?
speak;Joshua;Don't get the wrong idea.|I just meant for training.|And gambling.
speak;Joshua;Well, I suppose, but there's still a point to it all.
speak;Joshua;If I train with you, I'm going to become a better swordsman.|And if we train together, maybe we'll each learn something.

speak;Joshua;And there's something that I want to do soon when the war is over.|It's something that can't be done in a single day or overnight.|You could probably call this the biggest gamble of my entire life.|I'm going to have to hone my skills, and I'll need someone to help me.|What do you say, Marisa?|Won't you lend me a hand?
speak;Marisa;I'm good for fighting, and not much else.
speak;Joshua;You think?|I doubt that's true.|Well, think about it.
speak;Joshua;I know this is a gamble, but...|gambling is my hobby.
speak;Marisa;I won't.|But try to keep it interesting, all right?

speak;Joshua;Heh.|Then I'll do my best to keep you entertained.|And remember what I said...|Life is a gamble.|You never know what'll happen.|But don't worry.|I'm sure you won't be bored.|Besides, how often do you meet someone you can spar with?|Not to mention someone who can actually beat you!

name: SupportColmAndRennac
_source: speak;Colm;You're a thief, too, aren't you?|Do you think that's acceptable behavior for someone in the princess's entourage?

speak;Rennac;Ha ha ha!|Where'd you learn a big word like entourage, boy?|Not that it's any of your business, but Her Highness already knows about my...hobbies.|You're not, by any chance, trying to threaten me, are you?|That's funny.|I never thought I'd be reprimanded by a boy!
speak;Colm;Hey, old man, don't you talk down to ME!|I'm not a boy.|I'm Colm!|And I'm not threatening you, either.|I was just surprised that you're a thief because you dress so nicely.

speak;Rennac;I assume you're in the same trade.|Those rags are a dead giveaway.|Well, you may not take any pride in your appearance, but I'm different.|Do you see this jacket?|It has silk embroidery, a trend that I started in Carcino.|Where are the stitches, you ask?|They're on the inside of the jacket.|But I'm not going to show you.|The truly cultured man cares about every detail.|It would be a waste of my time to even try to explain it to a poor urchin like you.
speak;Colm;Why are you bragging about something so lame?|And I'm not a poor urchin!|Man, I've never met anyone as annoying as you!

speak;Rennac;Oh, don't be so sensitive, little urchin.|If you want to be like me, make more money.|Improve your skills.|The name of the game is making money.|Money is all that matters.|It's your only way out.|Work hard and escape from poverty.
speak;Colm;First of all, I don't want to be like you!|Second of all, I'll show you!
speak;Rennac;Well, don't pull a muscle, little urchin!
speak;Rennac;Hey, urchin, have you made any money yet?
speak;Colm;Stop calling me urchin!|I heard that your dad is a wealthy merchant in Carcino.
speak;Rennac;Yes.|So what?|My father is a wealthy merchant, and his son is a thief.|Great family, huh?
speak;Colm;If you're rich, you don't need to steal.|You can just buy whatever you want.
speak;Rennac;You are so green, boy.|Greener than the fruit I left out for a month.
speak;Colm;What's that supposed to mean?|I've never had dried fruit, so I don't know what you're talking about!
speak;Rennac;Oh, that's too bad.|Listen, urchin.|Merchants are always stingy.|It's part of who they are.|And my father was especially stingy.|He gave us nothing for free.

speak;Colm;We had to work for everything we had.|So my brothers and I learned the value of hard work from a young age.|And this just happens to be my job.|Get it?|It's not easy being the son of a merchant, huh?|Forced to work from a young age.|I had a tough childhood, too.|I always had to hunt and garden with my dad.|I guess our lives aren't so different after all, huh.
speak;Rennac;Er, a little hunting and gardening is quite different from actual work.|You can see that just by looking at how you and I turned out.
speak;Colm;Well!|I'll show you!|Maybe you'll wake up one morning and find that something important to you is gone!|Consider yourself warned, old man!
speak;Rennac;You know, warning people of your plans isn't really the most effective thieving strategy.|Anyhow, I look forward to seeing what you can muster.
speak;Rennac;Hi there, urchin.|I haven't heard you bragging in a while.|I thought maybe you gave up on your big plans.
speak;Colm;I'm more persistent than you think I am.|I came to see you because I remembered-|Wait, you haven't noticed yet?
speak;Rennac;What?|Did you actually steal something?|Don't tell me...|A ha!
speak;Colm;So you finally noticed!|Yes, I secretly stole only the embroidery off your precious jacket.|So, how's that for stealth?|That's some pretty fine thieving, if I do say so myself.
speak;Rennac;I see.|The embroidery IS missing.|Good work.|It's a little early for a victory celebration, though.|The embroidery was of a pony, correct?

speak;Rennac;Unfortunately for you, that was a fake.|I knew you would try to steal it, so I replaced it with a fake beforehand.|The real embroidery is of a phoenix.|But I won't show it to you.|Nope, never.
speak;Rennac;In this business, anything goes.|However, I'm impressed that you got as far as you did.|I definitely don't want you for an enemy.
speak;Colm;Heh heh heh...|Same here, I guess.|I'm glad that we're on the same side.|Now give me my boots!

name: SupportColmAndKyle
_source: speak;Colm;Kyle, do you have a minute?
speak;Kyle;Is something the matter with her?
speak;Colm;It was a while ago, but when she went to bed, she was...
speak;Kyle;What happened after she retired to her room?|Colm, don't toy with me.|Just tell me!
speak;Colm;The princess looked like she was having trouble falling asleep.|She kept pacing.

speak;Kyle;That's not good.|It's very important for her to get enough rest during this tough march.|This war has been very hard for Prince Ephraim and Princess Eirika.|I'm sure she's probably spent a few nights worrying, but-
speak;Colm;Hey!|I just remembered that I have this secret remedy my mother used to make.|It started off as a freckle cream, but it turns out that it works pretty well with insomnia, too.
speak;Kyle;Really.|That's a good idea.|I'm sure Prince Ephraim and Lady Eirika would love to have something like that.
speak;Colm;OK, then.|I'll give it to her next time I see her.|I'll let you know how it goes.
speak;Kyle;What is it this time, Colm?
speak;Kyle;And...?|That doesn't seem like news or anything.
speak;Colm;It's big news for me!|And for you, too!|The future of Renais is not looking good if he hates studying as much as I do.
speak;Kyle;Don't worry about it.|He might not like studying much, but no one is as bad as you.|Besides, if you're bringing this up to denigrate him, you are in serious trouble.
speak;Colm;Not at all!|I'm just worried about Prince Ephraim and Princess Eirika.
speak;Kyle;I understand.|But this news was really useless.|In the future, please only bring me relevant information.
speak;Colm;Kyle, I have some useful news!
speak;Colm;Heh heh heh...|Well, it's a secret about you.
speak;Kyle;A secret about me?|What is it?
speak;Colm;You have a girlfriend!|Her name is Meriella!|You send letters to her all the time, don't you!
speak;Kyle;Oh, that.|I've been meaning to tell you about her.
speak;Colm;I'm so glad to hear that, Kyle.|Let me know if you need to talk to someone.|Long-distance relationships can be hard.|I can't believe it!|Stuffy old Kyle is in love!
speak;Kyle;In love?|Me?|I think you're confused.|Meriella is not my girlfriend.|She is one of my teammates.
speak;Colm;Workplace romance, is it?|Say no more.|I understand.
speak;Kyle;Just shut up and listen to me.|Meriella is the alias we use for Renais knights on undercover missions.

speak;Kyle;Precisely.|We send mail addressed to Meriella, which only the Renais knights know.|The contents are always the same.|We let them know that Prince Ephraim and Princess Eirika are safe.|It's all written in secret code.|That's the letter I was sending.
speak;Colm;Even though we're in the middle of a war, does it really have to be so complicated?
speak;Kyle;Yes.|Better to be safe than sorry.
speak;Colm;I see.|Well, would you like me to deliver that letter?
speak;Kyle;No.|Every single soldier is important in this war.|We need you here.
speak;Kyle;Um...|Yes. Although you do bring me some pointless tidbits, you have also been a big help.

speak;Colm;Great!|This is so encouraging!|Until recently, I thought I'd never have any real connection with the knights.|But it's different now.|Now, I consider everyone involved in this war, especially the knights like you, to be my friends.|I will always fight for my friends!
speak;Kyle;Thank you, Colm.|Civilians and knights...|Together, we'll restore peace in Renais.

name: SupportGarciaAndDozla
_source: speak;Garcia;My name is Garcia.|Sir Dozla, I've been hearing a lot about you lately.
speak;Dozla;Only good things, I hope!|Ha ha ha!|I've heard of you, too, Sir Garcia.|Mostly about your incredible strength!|Hey, would you mind lifting this boulder?|Just kidding!|Ha ha ha!
speak;Garcia;Ha ha.|It's not a big deal.|Are you normally this...energetic?
speak;Dozla;Well, I stuffed myself, so I'm feeling pretty great!
speak;Garcia;You can't fight on an empty stomach.|Eating is very important to keep up your strength.|Especially breakfast.|I've heard that in some cultures, they call breakfast “first break.”
speak;Dozla;A fast what?|Huh?|Speak plainly!|I don't understand all this talking in circles.
speak;Garcia;We don't eat anything while we sleep, so it's as if we are fasting.|So, the meal you eat in the morning breaks that fast.|This means that breakfast is an especially important meal.
speak;Dozla;Huh.|Who would have thunk it?|The only thing I consumed this morning was knowledge!
speak;Dozla;Just that I make it a point to learn other disciplines.|You have to if you want to grow as a fighter.
speak;Garcia;I completely agree.|Young men in this army are strong in their specific fields, but weak in others.|The art of complete training has been lost on the younger generation, I'm afraid.

speak;Dozla;Yes, that's right!|Back in our day, fighters had to learn many disciplines in case they had to fill in for a wounded teammate.|I've always wanted to learn archery.|The delicate precision is the opposite of fighting with an axe.
speak;Garcia;Me, too.|Why don't we meet sometime and study it together?
speak;Dozla;I had a great time last time!
speak;Dozla;I just love sparring!|It's like having a conversation, except with weapons!
speak;Garcia;You DO know that you're not supposed to swing the bow like an axe, right?|Ha ha!
speak;Dozla;I was only clowning around!|I'm recalling that a certain someone loaded the arrow in the wrong direction and nearly impaled his shoulder.|Hmmm. Now, who could that have been?
speak;Garcia;That was a defect in the arrow!
speak;Dozla;Ha ha ha ha ha!|I'm sure!
speak;Garcia;Maybe you just can't teach old dogs new tricks.
speak;Dozla;I don't believe that's true at all.|You're magnificent with an axe.|How hard can it be to learn something new?
speak;Garcia;No, you're the great one.|You're a menace to the enemy!
speak;Dozla;Where did you learn to fight like that?

speak;Garcia;Well, I used to lead troops in Renais.|I learned the basics there...|Once I retired, I was living on a mountain.|My daily chores involved swinging an axe, although just for splitting firewood.
speak;Dozla;See?|You learned how to apply your skills to different fields.|Maybe archery just isn't our thing.|We should try something else.
speak;Dozla;It can't be that difficult to learn.|As far as I can tell, it's just a bunch of arm waving and shouting gibberish.
speak;Garcia;That did not go as well as I had hoped.
speak;Dozla;Well, that's not entirely true, is it.
speak;Garcia;It would have helped if you hadn't whacked me in the head with the staff.
speak;Dozla;I didn't mean to hit you!|You just got in the way when I was...conjuring.
speak;Garcia;I still have a lump on my head.
speak;Dozla;I feel badly about it, all right?|Besides, I think you're forgetting that I also healed you with that staff!
speak;Garcia;No, you didn't!|You burned my beard clear off!
speak;Dozla;You have to admit, though, you looked quite dashing without that beard.|It took at least ten years off of your appearance.|No, at least twenty!
speak;Garcia;You really think so?|I can't stop smelling burnt hair.
speak;Dozla;But, wait!|At least give me credit for making it grow back that quickly.
speak;Garcia;Very well.|It grew back nicely.|Thank you.
speak;Garcia;This little foray into other disciplines has certainly taught me a lot.
speak;Dozla;Me, too!|After all this, sword fighting should be a piece of cake!

name: SupportJoshuaAndInnes
_source: speak;Joshua;Hey, you're Prince Innes, aren't you?|I'm Joshua.|Nice to meet you.
speak;Joshua;Well, now that we know each other...|What say we play a quick game of chance, hm?
speak;Innes;Hm?|What are you planning on doing with that coin?

speak;Joshua;We're gonna have a little wager.|What else?|If I'm going to fight alongside someone, I want to know him.|And there's no better way to get to know someone than a friendly wager!|So...|What do you say to a starter bet of...1,000?

speak;Joshua;Hey now.|I always take gambling seriously.|Always.|Whether you live or die on the field often comes down to luck.|Every fight, you're putting your life in someone else's hands.|You should be glad to meet up with such a lucky guy.
speak;Innes;You may rely on luck, but I prefer raw skill.|However, we might as well.|Put your money where your mouth is.
speak;Joshua;Now you're talking!|Right, here we go!|Heads or tails?|What's your call?
speak;Joshua;Let's see what we've got...|Oh, well.|It's heads.|Too bad, Your Highness.|You lost.
speak;Innes;That's strange...|My eyes never fail me, but I could have sworn-|Hm.|There seems to be more to betting than meets the eye.
speak;Joshua;Figure that out already?|You're a quick study.
speak;Innes;Yeah.|Let's try that again.|I'll get it this time...
speak;Joshua;...Heads again.|That's ten losses in a row.
speak;Innes;I don't care.|Next bet.|Double or nothing.|Tails.
speak;Joshua;Shouldn't you stop soon?|Maybe you've got the cash back home, but you're on the road.|And I'm willing to bet you're not carrying that much on you.
speak;Innes;No, keep going.|I don't feel like quitting on a bad streak.
speak;Joshua;Fine, fine...|But then can we call it quits?|You've let me win enough, and I don't want to bleed you dry.
speak;Innes;No.|I won't let you leave, not while you're still ahead.|Hurry up.|We don't have the luxury of time here.
speak;Joshua;What's that saying?|The cooler the head, the hotter he bets?|Something like that.|And you seem pretty cool most of the time.|I guess the old saying is true.
speak;Joshua;You can't be serious.|You want to keep going?
speak;Joshua;...Oh, brother.|Your Highness, I have a little admission to make here.|You have no chance of winning.|The whole thing is rigged.
speak;Joshua;Yeah.|You flip the coin|...like this.|Then catch it in the hand.|I'm the one holding the coin.|I can turn it over any way I choose just by moving my palm a bit.|Like this.

speak;Innes;Hmm...|That's how you did it...|I knew you were up to something.|It was straining my disbelief that you could keep winning like that.|Strange that I couldn't catch on to your little trick, though.

speak;Joshua;That's nice of you to say, but I'm sure you must have suspected.|There's a guy who hangs out near a pub in Jehanna.|He's real smooth.|His secret is to mix in just enough losses to make it look plausible.|If you ever go there, you'll know the guy I'm talking about right away.
speak;Innes;Interesting.|I've never had any experience with this sort of thing.|One only has so much time when he's groomed to become the king, you know.

speak;Joshua;I can imagine.|But a king must have a wide range of knowledge, don't you think?|When I was a journeyman, I lost a lot of money to scams like this.|I started learning these tricks so they couldn't be used on me anymore!|It's all rubbish, innit?|But it's not a bad thing to add to your experience.
speak;Innes;I must hand it to you, you have a point.|Some things, you can only learn firsthand, on the field.
speak;Joshua;Well, I've given away enough of my secrets for one day.|I'll give you back all the money I took you for, so go easy on me...
speak;Innes;There's no need to give it back.|That I failed to see your trick was my own failing.
speak;Joshua;You serious?|All right.|Good deal.|You're a good man.|Let's just call this your tuition fee, eh?
speak;Joshua;Now what?|What is it this time?
speak;Innes;We're still in the middle of the bet.|We'll pick up where we left off.
speak;Joshua;Are you saying...|you want to keep going?
speak;Innes;Naturally.|You've revealed your secrets to me.|My luck is bound to change.|I feel a winning streak coming on.
speak;Joshua;...Oh, brother.|Well, you're persistent, I'll give you that much.|Call it in the air.

name: SupportInnesAndTana
_source: speak;Tana;I'm so glad to find you safe!|Everyone back home is worried.|Don't you worry, though.|I'll protect you from now on.
speak;Innes;Tana, what are you doing here?|You have no place on the battlefield.|I want you to return to Castle Frelia immediately.
speak;Tana;Why does everyone say that!?|I am one of Frelia's pegasus knights and a trained soldier!|I studied with Syrene and Vanessa, two of Frelia's finest!
speak;Innes;And you're also a Frelian princess.|You should not be fighting.|What would happen if you were injured?
speak;Innes;Why does she always have to be like this?
speak;Tana;Did you see me out on the battlefield, Innes?
speak;Tana;I knew I made the right decision, coming out here.|I feel like our strategy is becoming much better, as is our fighting.|You do agree, don't you, Innes?
speak;Innes;I grant you some small credit for your achievements on the field of war.|However, I still insist that you return to Frelia.

speak;Innes;It's true that you've gained some experience out on the battlefield.|But your ignorance of the world around you is simply appalling.|It must be tough for a pampered castle brat like you to interact with soldiers.

speak;Tana;If you can say something like that to your own sister, I'm more worried about you.|Even when you're right-and your judgment is good, I know-|you're so blunt that I don't think many people will want to listen to you.
speak;Innes;Never mind about me.|This is about you, Tana.|If you keep traveling with us, someone might take advantage of your naivet?|More than anything, I can't allow that Ephraim to-
speak;Tana;What are you saying?|Do you really think Ephraim and I-
speak;Innes;No.|Even if you're not interested in him in the slightest, I...|I simply do not want to see you get hurt.
speak;Tana;Innes, what are you suggesting?|If that's the way you're going to be, I just won't talk to you anymore!
speak;Innes;Why can't you listen to your brother?|Why are you always so stubborn!?
speak;Tana;You're the stubborn one, Innes!|Why can't you understand how I feel?|You're my only brother, and I have no one else on whom I can rely...|I don't want to waste our time together arguing!

speak;Tana;You don't know how much I envy Eirika and Ephraim for their closeness.|They understand one another's thoughts and feelings perfectly all the time!|Why aren't we like that?|Why do you never understand me, Innes?
speak;Innes;Tana, wait.|I don't say these things because I hate you.
speak;Tana;That's a lie!|You're always so mean to me, Innes!|You make no effort to understand how I feel.
speak;Innes;That's not true.|I'm still your brother, and I think I know you better than anyone else.
speak;Innes;Absolutely.|Do you remember the incident with the crown?

speak;Tana;Oh!|I remember.|It was when I was very little, and I lost Father's crown.|He was so angry with me.|I thought he would never stop yelling.|I was so terrified of his wrath, and I just couldn't stop crying.|I honestly believed Father would throw me in the dungeon!|But you searched the castle from top to bottom, and you found the crown.|And I remember what you told Father when you brought it back to him.|“I took your crown, Father.|I wanted to see what it would look like on my head.”|I remember how happy I was when I heard Father laughing at your words.|I thought I was the luckiest girl in the world to have a brother like you.
speak;Innes;I know how you feel better than anyone else.|And that's no lie.
speak;Tana;Innes...|I understand now why you said what you said.|But please, forgive me for being here, for not going home.|I simply wanted to be near you, my beloved brother.
speak;Innes;You win.|I'll let you stay.|But you be sure to apologize to our father when we return home.|And don't worry too much.|I'll be there with you when you do.
speak;Tana;You're the best brother anyone could have!
speak;Innes;And you are quite a handful, Sister.

name: SupportInnesAndGerik
_source: speak;Innes;Gerik...|I'm sorry you had to see that ugly side of me.
speak;Innes;At Renvall, when you stayed by me.|If not for your loyalty, I would have fallen into the hands of those mercenaries.
speak;Gerik;Ah, well, that's my job, innit?|But what's your point?|This is unlike you, Prince.

speak;Innes;I've guided men into battle countless times before that day.|I've always tried to be a model commander, to guide others by my example.|But...I found that many of my soldiers wanted a less severe example to follow.
speak;Innes;But you're different.|I've known that from the day we first met.|How do you stay so composed in the heat of battle?
speak;Gerik;I don't know how to answer that...|I suppose it's just in my nature.|Long discussions on the battlefield, however, are not.|Let's go already.
speak;Innes;Nice work, Gerik...|I see the Desert Tiger is still as fierce as ever.

speak;Gerik;I can't believe my skill with the blade is known in circles as high as yours.|Let me tell you, I didn't get into this line of work because I like fighting.|It was a twist of fate that started me on this path...
speak;Innes;Really?|But I've heard of your fame from no less a person than my father.|He tells me your name was once known from shore to shore on this continent.
speak;Gerik;The past is the past.|I was just doing what I had to.|If I hadn't, I never would have survived.|But there's something about combat that just doesn't agree with my nature.
speak;Innes;If that's the case, why are you with these mercenaries?

speak;Gerik;Ahh...|The answer is so simple, you'll probably laugh.|Back when I was a kid, a friend from my village said he wanted to be a mercenary.|He said he was going to be famous, the greatest warrior in all the land.|No matter how many times I told him to give it up, he wouldn't listen to me.|Well, one day, he left for Jehanna.|I didn't know what else to do, so I went with him and joined the guild, too.|Stupid reason, isn't it?|Anyway...|I didn't particularly like fighting, and while I wasn't opposed to the money, I certainly wasn't in it for fame...|I just couldn't let my friend go off and get killed.
speak;Innes;And where is this friend now?
speak;Gerik;He went off and got killed.

speak;Gerik;So there was no reason for me to continue being a mercenary...|But then there were other men who I considered to be my friends.|I couldn't bring myself to abandon them...|And so the years passed and here I am.|The thing is I can't stand to see my friends die.|But if you're in this business long enough, people around you get killed.|It happens.|The only thing you can do is keep moving forward and try not to think about it.|So...|Yes, I'd have a problem if you got yourself killed.|I've got no place else to go, and I'm tired of trying to forget.
speak;Innes;Hmph...|Do you really think I'd lose so easily?|It won't do for you to underestimate me.

speak;Innes;There's something I've always assumed to be true...|Those born to royalty cannot show others any weaknesses or deficiencies.|If they're not perfect at all times, their enemies will take advantage of them.

speak;Innes;But meeting you has made me rethink that belief.|My father told me before I left that I should watch you and learn from you.|At the time, I believed there was nothing a mercenary could teach me.|Now I know better.|I am thankful to both my father and you.
speak;Gerik;That's enough of that.|In my opinion, you're much finer than I could ever be.|The way you live, your manners, and your bearing...|I could never pull it off.
speak;Gerik;Look at you!|You're full of confidence.|You've got pride.|When I first met you, I thought,|“What a high-handed dandy.”
speak;Innes;Did you just call me...a dandy?

speak;Gerik;But that's just who you are.|Being proud is not always a bad thing.|You must have worked yourself near to death to preserve that pride.|What I mean is that you never make excuses for losing or being beaten up.|No matter the pain you face or hardship, you keep on fighting to honor that pride.|It's what defines you, and I can't say that I don't admire it.

speak;Innes;It comes naturally.|I will be king one day, and I will make Frelia the greatest nation in all the world.|It will be a wonderful kingdom of wealth and power.|When that day comes, I will command you to become general and lead Frelia's armies.|No, I'll have you come and ask me to make you general.

name: SupportInnesAndLarachel
_source: speak;Larachel;Yes...|You know, I believe this is our first chance to speak privately.|I am L'Arachel of the Theocracy of Rausten.|It's a pleasure to meet you.
speak;Innes;I believe you already know my name.|I am Innes, prince of Frelia.
speak;Larachel;Speaking of Frelia...|Oh, I remember, the seafood was delicious there.
speak;Innes;Yes.|I would agree that the fish of my homeland is not unpleasant.
speak;Larachel;Yes.|However it does not compare with that of my home, Rausten.
speak;Innes;Is that so?|I know not what fish your country has to offer, but I have a hard time imagining they could be that much tastier than our own.
speak;Larachel;Your doubt is not surprising.|Once this war is over, you must come and visit Rausten.|I think it best if you try a wide variety of our fish for yourself.

speak;Innes;That's a good idea.|I will most certainly do so.|And perhaps you have not tasted all the fish Frelia has to offer.|To be sure, you should visit again.|Perhaps a culinary exchange is in order.|It may be that you change your opinion.
speak;Larachel;We'll see.|Very well, I accept your invitation.|I will visit your country once more and taste your national dishes.
speak;Innes;Are you sure you're supposed to be here?|I wonder if you're truly here with the permission of your superiors.
speak;Larachel;Of-of course I am!|What gives you the right to speak to me in such a manner?
speak;Innes;Well, I have heard a bit about your wild behavior...
speak;Larachel;H-how rude you are!|If I were not a holy woman, I would beat you senseless.

speak;Innes;How savage YOU are.|Perhaps you could learn self-control by observing Frelia's pegasus knights.|Yes, there's something I'd like to show you.|When the Frelia's pegasi gather in Walles Forest...|It's a spectacle of such beauty...
speak;Larachel;If it is beauty you seek, then Rausten is second to none.|Do you know of Rausten's lofty peak Mount Mimir.|I pity those who die without having gazed upon its breathtaking beauty.
speak;Innes;If you recommend it so highly, then yes, I would indeed like to see it.
speak;Larachel;Yes.|That would be splendid indeed.|But there are many more equally beautiful places in Rausten.
speak;Innes;Then perhaps you should tell me about them for future reference.|And in return, I shall take time to tell you about the beautiful places in my kingdom.
speak;Larachel;Yes, I would love to hear more.
speak;Innes;The Theocracy of Rausten certainly sounds like a spectacular land.
speak;Larachel;As does Frelia, much more than I imagined it would.|And yet...
speak;Innes;You mean to ask which is the more spectacular?|Is that it?
speak;Larachel;What?|That's no question at all!|Rausten is clearly superior in every way.
speak;Innes;I expected you would say so.|But what of the truth?|Your opinion is subjective, is it not?
speak;Larachel;Well...um...|All opinions are subjective, but I'm sure an objective evaluation would yield the same result.
speak;Innes;To prove that, we will need some fair and impartial third in our discussion.
speak;Larachel;Indeed!|And I have a splendid idea.|Let the pair from Renais judge.|Surely Ephraim and Eirika can come to a proper decision.
speak;Innes;Of course.|I agree completely.|I think I should remind the two of all the wonder Frelia holds.

speak;Larachel;Then it's decided.|They will visit both of our homes, and we'll show them such splendor as to leave them breathless.|Invitations to tour our two nations will surely have them overjoyed.
speak;Larachel;It would be natural.|Very well then.|Let us deal with this evil and take those two home with us.|First and foremost, it is a competition to see whose land is more magnificent!
speak;Innes;I can see this whole affair has you very enthralled.|I cannot say where this little competition will lead us...|But I am more than happy to go up against you.
speak;Larachel;Don't blame me if you regret our contest later, though.|You may be composed before others, but you'll surely be lonely on your own.
speak;Innes;Be warned yourself.|Your words here may prove embarrassing to you later.
speak;Larachel;It's not a problem.|This is just another contest in the name of all that is holy and true.

name: SupportLuteAndKyle
_source: speak;Lute;I'm sorry, were you talking to me?
speak;Kyle;There's nobody else here, is there?
speak;Kyle;I beg your pardon.|I should have introduced myself.|Kyle, of the Knights of Renais.
speak;Lute;Ah, I see.|And I am Lute, mage of profound genius.
speak;Kyle;Very well, Lute.|The pleasure is mine.|To tell you the truth, I've been looking for you.
speak;Lute;Has someone issued a search notice?|Or is there a bounty on my head?|Or is this perhaps a private matter?
speak;Kyle;I...guess it would be that last one.|I have a favor to ask.
speak;Lute;What would it be?|My requests are classified into seven categories and 25 items.
speak;Kyle;I don't know how it would be classified, but...I want you to help us fight.

speak;Kyle;I'm a strong believer that morale is best served by good leadership.|A unit of knights, all trained by Renais's finest generals.|But we're fighting no ordinary foe, and we need more diverse skills.|That's where you come in.|Because you can use magic, you could be invaluable in helping me develop unique battle strategies.
speak;Lute;So that's what you wanted me for, is it?
speak;Kyle;How about it?|Would you do it?

speak;Kyle;I should warn you, I spend my time on the front line.|I ride out to meet the enemy head-|on rather than attacking from afar.|It's a much riskier prospect than supporting from the rear guard.|Is that going to be a problem?

speak;Kyle;Excellent!|I appreciate your help.|I expect we'll be able to generate some stunning tactics together.|You don't need to stay at the front the whole time.|I'll give you a cue when to approach.
speak;Lute;Got it.|I'll do whatever you say.
speak;Lute;You have nothing to worry about.|There's no one better than me!
speak;Kyle;I was right about you.|You've been a great help to us all.
speak;Lute;Well, of course I have!|I told you there's no one better than me!
speak;Kyle;Magic is an incredibly powerful force, isn't it?|Sturdy armor, tough hide, it makes no difference to magic.|I'm in awe of it.
speak;Lute;You're not so bad yourself.|You're an incredible fighter.
speak;Kyle;Yep.|When I was young, there was a lad I hated losing to.|Every day, I trained harder and harder in hopes of defeating him.
speak;Lute;So what happened?|Did you finally beat him?
speak;Kyle;Uh...|Not as such, no.|But I haven't lost to him in a while, either.|We're evenly matched.|I think we force one another to improve.
speak;Lute;I see.|It's always good to have someone against whom you measure yourself.|Aren't you glad you have this personal adversary?
speak;Kyle;Uh-huh.|You know, I think this is the longest conversation we've had.
speak;Kyle;Well, uh...|Not to sound rude, but I didn't take you as the kind to be interested in others.
speak;Lute;No, it's not rude at all.|I just...|got a little interested in you.
speak;Kyle;I see.|Keep up the good work.
speak;Kyle;Hooo...|What a fight!|How are you holding up, Lute?
speak;Lute;No problem, sir.|I could keep this up all day!
speak;Kyle;That's good to hear.|But don't push yourself...|You're vital to my strategy!
speak;Lute;Of course I am!|There's no one better than me!
speak;Kyle;I'd have to agree.|This would be a lot harder without you along.|This might seem forward, but...|What do you do when you're not, well, fighting in wars?
speak;Lute;Me?|Oh, I'm a student of magic.
speak;Kyle;I guessed that much.|What I mean is, do you have any hobbies?
speak;Kyle;That's right.|Take me, for example.|I like to collect carved figurines of animals.|I have a small collection of them back home at Renais.|How about you?
speak;Kyle;Monk-watching?|What are you talking about?|Maybe I should ask a different question.|Do you have any favorite foods?
speak;Lute;Out of everything I've had, curry of dried toad is my favorite.
speak;Lute;I don't cook much, but I'm sure I'd be good at it.|I mean, I can cook with a single word, no fire necessary!
speak;Kyle;Ha ha ha ha ha!|I never get bored talking to you.|I can't explain it, but I find you so refreshing!
speak;Lute;Really?|I like talking to you, too.
speak;Kyle;Why don't you come to Renais once the war is over?
speak;Kyle;Ha!|No objections?T|hat's your answer?|Well, all right, then.|Let's focus on getting through this war first, though.
speak;Kyle;I'm glad to have you with us.

name: SupportNatashaAndKnoll
_source: speak;Knoll;I know you...|You're Natasha, from the temple.
speak;Natasha;Yes.|I remember seeing you many times back in Grado.|But this is the first time we've ever actually spoken.

speak;Knoll;I don't know what it is, but clerics and mages seem to be like oil and water.|And we mages can be an enigmatic bunch at times.|Shadowy and sinister...|Or at least, that's how I've always imagined you clerics saw us.
speak;Natasha;Oh, no!|I never-|Well, no.|You're right.|We had few dealings with the mages.|But that's in the past.|I have a question for you, Master Knoll.
speak;Knoll;I think I can guess.|It's about the Sacred Stones and Prince Lyon, is it?
speak;Natasha;It is.|My mentor died...trying to warn us about the threat our Sacred Stone posed.|I want to know the truth.|What is Emperor Vigarde up to?|What is Prince Lyon's role in this?
speak;Knoll;There are as many truths out there as there are people to tell them.|Perhaps it's best simply to choose the truth with which you are most comfortable.

speak;Knoll;In the eyes of your mentor, I would imagine we must have seemed quite evil.|He imagined our magical studies using the Sacred Stone were sacrilege.|I suspect he quite loathed the ancient magics he called “dark.”
speak;Natasha;You're wrong...|My mentor wasn't like that at all!|And isn't this war the direct result of all your dark magic research?

speak;Knoll;Hm...|Well, I suppose you are right about that.|Your magic stems from faith in the unknowable, the divine presence.|In contrast, dark magic stems from knowledge, from understanding.|We distrust what we do not understand, and we strive to know the unknowable.|Perhaps our disciplines truly are incompatible.

speak;Knoll;...Our researches ended in miserable failure.|Grado's Sacred Stone was shattered.|Prince Lyon, corrupted...|And this whole tragedy that unfolds around us even now.|It's true.|We mages have triggered this age's greatest calamity.
speak;Natasha;But why?|What was it all for?|What did you hope to accomplish with the power of the Sacred Stone?
speak;Knoll;All Prince Lyon wanted was to help people...and we are his servants.
speak;Knoll;We read of a spell entitled the time shear.|It causes, in effect, a hole in time.|This spell warps time, punches a hole through cause and effect.

speak;Knoll;We lack the knowledge to reproduce this ancient spell today.|Prince Lyon, however, was convinced that we could unravel its secret.|He felt we could use it to predict-|and even prevent-future events.

speak;Knoll;Oh, we dedicated years to studying this spell.|You see, the greater the disaster, the farther it sends ripples through time.|We learned to read these ripples from the future, hoping to save lives.|If we could know when a disaster would strike, we could evacuate people.|We could save millions of lives.
speak;Natasha;But...|It seems so, so blasphemous.|That worldly creatures should take control of fate, it-
speak;Knoll;Are you saying that, knowing the future, we should do nothing?|We should simply allow people to die in order to preserve “fate”?

speak;Knoll;I'm sorry.|I don't mean to sound hostile.|Prince Lyon himself was troubled by these same doubts, you see.|But we pressed on with our studies.|We felt it was our duty, in the interest of all Grado's people.

speak;Knoll;Perhaps we were bitter that we receive no credit for aiding Grado.|That we receive no accolades for our research, for the benefit it brings.|I do not know.|But we pressed on, nonetheless.|The misconceptions linking the ancient magics to “evil” die hard and slow.|Prince Lyon sought to change that.|He wanted, as we all wanted, to prove that our magic had good uses.

speak;Knoll;With our aid, Prince Lyon predicted a great storm rising in the south.|He barred ships from leaving port, and, oh, how the people complained.|But the storm came, and the seas raged.|We saved countless lives.|And Prince Lyon cared not at all if the people loved him for it.|He only wanted them to be safe.
speak;Knoll;And now, I see it all so clearly.|All our research amounts to nothing.|All I can do now is lament our hunger for knowledge.|Our greed.
speak;Knoll;...Still have questions, do you?|I have told you all that I know.

speak;Natasha;I'm not sure you did.|You said that you could see...ripples of future disasters, is that it?|And the greater the disaster, the more clearly you could read it?|Does that mean you saw something?|Some tremendous disaster to come?
speak;Natasha;And in knowing about the disaster, Lyon thought he could prevent it.|Could he have...|Was he studying the Sacred Stone to find a way to prevent this disaster?
speak;Knoll;And what will you do, now that you know this, too?|Haven't you called such knowledge blasphemous?
speak;Natasha;I...don't know what to do.|If my mentor were here, I think he might be able to guide me.|But I'm still so inexperienced.|I feel lost in this dilemma.
speak;Natasha;But how can I not act on this?|If I do nothing, knowing that something terrible will happen...|If I could have helped... I...|I don't know what to do.
speak;Knoll;...Within five years, half of Grado will be destroyed.

speak;Knoll;In the southern half of the continent, there will be a terrible quake.|The ground will shake violently.|The earth will crack open wide.|Cities will fall.|Fields will burn in the earth's hot blood.|Few will survive.|This is what we have foreseen.
speak;Knoll;I advise you to leave Grado.|You might be able to escape the disaster if you head north to Renais or Frelia.
speak;Natasha;No...|I can't do that.|When this disaster strikes, people will need help and healing.|If I could help them even a little by staying behind...
speak;Knoll;You would willingly risk certain death to save a handful of people?
speak;Natasha;If I died serving Grado, I would have no regrets, Master Knoll.|Thank you for sharing this.|I will make the most of this knowledge.

speak;Knoll;Spoken like a true cleric.|You would drop everything without hesitation just to help others.|This is the difference between mages and priests.|Knowledge versus sacrifice.|Perhaps you might allow me to join you when the time comes...
speak;Knoll;If I am to honor Prince Lyon's intentions, I cannot flee this.|I am not sure how best I can help, but I do not want anyone to die.|Not if, by my action, I can save them.
speak;Natasha;I understand how you feel, Master Knoll...|Let our strengths be united, then, for the common good.

name: SupportNatashaAndCormag
_source: speak;Cormag;Oh, great.|Perfect timing.|You're a priestess, aren't you?
speak;Cormag;Sorry, I'm in a bit of a hurry here.|Uh, could you heal this little guy for me?
speak;Cormag;Yeah, what's the matter?|Can't you do kittens?
speak;Natasha;No, that's not it.|It's just, I was a little surprised to-
speak;Cormag;Whatever.|Doesn't matter.|If you can heal him, hop to it!
speak;Natasha;There.|He should be fine now.|Aren't you a lucky little kitty?|This sweet man saved you!
speak;Cormag;Sweet man?|Me?|Heh.|Lady, you don't know me.|But thanks for saving him.
speak;Natasha;Not at all.|I couldn't let the little guy suffer.
speak;Cormag;The name's Cormag.|I'm glad I ran into you.
speak;Natasha;I'm just glad I could help.|My name is Natasha.
speak;Cormag;Well, I owe you one for saving the cat.|If you need any help, just call out, and I'll be here.
speak;Natasha;Yes, that's right.|How is the kitty doing?
speak;Cormag;I took him back to his mother.|I figured he belonged back with his mom.
speak;Cormag;How about you?|Where are your parents in all this?
speak;Natasha;I haven't seen them since I joined the clerical order.|We would write, but it's been a while since I heard from them.|I wonder how they are.|I've been worried about them.
speak;Cormag;I thought so!|You know what?|That's where I'm from, too!|Where were you born?|I'm from the south myself.
speak;Natasha;I was born in a village near the Renais border.
speak;Cormag;Ah, well, you've got nothing to worry about then.|When I joined the army, I was stationed near the border.|Worst thing you've got to worry about there is bandits.
speak;Natasha;Really?|That's so good to hear.|Thank you for telling me that.|I get so worried.
speak;Cormag;Ah, there.|That's a nice smile you've got there.|Cheers me up just looking at it, it does.|Don't worry too much about your parents, Natasha.
speak;Natasha;I won't, Cormag.|And thank you.|I mean it.
speak;Cormag;What's the matter?|You've got your gloomy face on again.
speak;Natasha;Doesn't this all get hard for you?
speak;Natasha;Ever since this started, we've been fighting nothing but Grado soldiers.|These are our countrymen.|Our families...

speak;Natasha;Every battle we win, I see only how many casualties we've caused.|I'm a healer, but to win this, I must turn my back on my countrymen.|I have to let them suffer, when all I want to do is help them.|But...
speak;Natasha;Grado is responsible for all of this.|Our homeland...|Grado has caused so many deaths now.|We have no choice but to fight.

speak;Cormag;Ah.|You see it now.|That's the sad irony of the battlefield.|I ride a wyvern and use my spear to bring down men who should be my allies.|We each joined this cause in hopes of bringing Grado to its senses.|Our country has set the world on its ear, and it's up to us to right things.

speak;Cormag;You know something, Natasha?|You should never be ashamed of the fact that you're from Grado.|You have no debt to pay, no burden of guilt to bear.|Grado was once a magnificent country.|Do what you can to restore that glory.|It took only a handful of men to turn Grado down the wrong path, but perhaps a mere handful of soldiers can set things right again.
speak;Natasha;I understand, Cormag.|I'll do what I know to be right, no matter what.|I feel like a heavy fog has been lifted from my heart.|Thank you.
speak;Cormag;Ah, I just wanted to see that lovely smile on your face again.|You and me, we've got lots to talk about, I think.|Let's do this again.

name: SupportCormagAndArtur
_source: speak;Cormag;Hey, what's going on here?|Don't get too close now.|It may look calm now, but it's got a dangerous side.|Like me.
speak;Cormag; I'm Cormag.|Nice to meet you.
speak;Artur;You, too, Sir Cormag.|It's a pleasure.

speak;Artur;It's not so much interest as it is, well, fascination, if you will.|The way how they fly in the sky at will...|and their powerful limbs.|I've seen them from a distance before, but I've never seen one up close...|Do you think it would mind if I were to touch it?

speak;Cormag;Nah, go right ahead.|But wyverns can be proud.|They won't warm up to anyone they think unworthy.|Took me three years before this one would let me ride on his back.|Oh, he hated me at first.|Always snarling and snatching at me...|I don't know how many times he threw me when I tried to ride him.
speak;Artur;R-really?|Maybe I should keep my distance then.
speak;Cormag;No, he seems to like you.
speak;Cormag;He hasn't tried to eat your face yet, for one thing.|Maybe he can sense your, what'd you call it, fascination?|Yeah, maybe it won't take too long for you two to be friends.
speak;Artur;Hm.|Well then, it's very nice to meet you, Sir Cormag's Wyvern?
speak;Cormag;His name's Genarog.|Next time you're around, come say hi.
speak;Cormag;If it isn't Artur.|What's the rush?
speak;Artur;I've been thinking about how to become friends with Genarog.|I was thinking perhaps he might like it if I gave him something.
speak;Cormag;You want to give Genarog a gift?
speak;Artur;Yes.|It's an amulet made of a star stone.|According to legend, those who carry star stones are blessed from above.|It's customary to wear them as amulets in Renais, and I thought...
speak;Cormag;I see...|But that's your amulet, isn't it?
speak;Artur;No need to worry for me, Sir Cormag.|I pray every morning and every night.
speak;Cormag;Well, if that's the case, then we'll take it.|Look at that, Genarog!|All right, Artur, I want you to place it in his saddlebag.
speak;Artur;I'm a little scared, but I'll give it a try!
speak;Artur;All right...|The saddlebag...|This one right here?|There you go...
speak;Artur;Sir Cormag, look!|Genarog licked my hand!
speak;Cormag;Whoa, not bad...|Not bad at all, Artur.|I've never once seen him lick anyone's hand but mine.
speak;Cormag;Yeah, and it took him two years before he'd even do that!|You and he seem to be getting along famously, as they say.
speak;Artur;That makes me happy, Sir Cormag.|I'm glad he likes the amulet.
speak;Cormag;I think he likes you more than he likes that amulet, honestly.
speak;Artur;Really, Sir Cormag?|May I talk to him again?
speak;Cormag;Sure, anytime.|We're looking forward to it.|Both of us.
speak;Cormag;I should apologize to you, Artur.
speak;Artur;What's wrong, Sir Cormag?|Did something happen?

speak;Cormag;The star-stone amulet that you so generously gave Genarog...|It got shattered when an archer attacked us.|It's not all bad, though.|That stone stopped the arrow cold.|Saved both me AND Genarog, it did.|Had that amulet been not there, we wouldn't be here right now.
speak;Artur;That's unfortunate, but I'm glad the amulet worked!|I'll have to make a prayer of thanks for the stone's protection.
speak;Cormag;Well, we owe you, Artur.|And it's not exactly a perfect trade, but...|Here.
speak;Artur;This...|This looks like a wyvern stone!
speak;Artur;Yes, very!|Where on earth did you...

speak;Cormag;Genarog had it.|I didn't have any idea what it was.|I figured maybe you'd know something about it.|And it looks like I was right, wasn't I?|You know what it's worth?|Well, like I said, it's yours.|Keep it.
speak;Cormag;Sure.|You don't mind, now, do you, Genarog?
